{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3254397,"name":"Marcus","username":"marcusbernstein","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/marcusbernstein/{size}/125679_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-16T15:00:14.454Z","cooked":"

Everyone here has a great swerve code library. What’s the best resource to learn about swerve in English? How does it work? What is happening in the code architecture-/math-wise? What are the principles (vectors, sensors, recent best practices, etc)?

Looking for a digestible video, slides, whitepaper, animation, etc to learn and teach with.

Sent from the bandwagon,
-Marcus

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2023-11-16T15:00:14.454Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":37,"reads":414,"readers_count":413,"score":357.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":444416,"topic_slug":"how-does-swerve-work-in-english-not-java","display_username":"Marcus","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23867,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Your Favorite JnJ Associate Engineer"},"post_url":"/t/how-does-swerve-work-in-english-not-java/444416/1","custom_user_title":"Your Favorite JnJ Associate Engineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3254402,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-16T15:06:52.443Z","cooked":"

I appreciate the explicit “not Java”. That was absolutely nessecary!

The last F.U.N. FIRST rewind about drivetrain history had a lot of great info about drivetrain and a lot of talk about swerve in general. We just watched it yesterday night as part of our meeting opening.

In general reading through the guides from REV (and also other Swerve module vendors) and WpiLib are useful as well. Rev is specific to their module, WPIlib is about the kinematics in programming, but it talks about the topics involved like Odometry on the root page for that section.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Swerve Drive Kinematics

The SwerveDriveKinematics class is a useful tool that converts between a ChassisSpeeds object and several SwerveModuleState objects, which contains velocities and angles for each swerve module of a...

docs.revrobotics.com

MAXSwerve

The more technical documents you read and see the commonalities between the various modules the better you understand it. They all use the same programming in the end so it’s a matter of:

  • Quality of the Parts, plastic or metal?
  • Is the design robust?
  • How is the build process in difficulty and time cost?
  • How well will it reset at runtime?
  • Do you have a maintenance checklist for each module?
  • Do you have enough spares?

Having not done Swerve for FRC but every other drivetrain type I’m hitting the books hard in advance.

This is the OG paper on the math: Paper: 4 wheel independent drive & independent steering ("swerve")

It allowed me to program my first swerve drive in Scratch (which is not Java, lol): https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/393022881/

Couldn’t recommend this video more for explaining the code side of it! It became my best friend while I learned how Swerve works. Our team wasn’t new to swerve when I learned it, but I tasked with re-coding it and having to explain it to our rookie students.

Not sure how helpful this is, but I have our Swerve Overview presentation that we used to teach newer students the basics of swerve in software. It doesn’t go very far into detail, as it was just intended as an overview. The speaker notes contain what I said when I gave the presentation. Still, I would definitely recommend that video!
